header.title: Ars Almadel: Part IV of the Lemegeton

central_thesis: The Ars Almadel presents a system for invoking Chief Angels from the four Altitudes of the World, attributed to King Solomon, to gain wisdom and effect changes in the physical and spiritual realms by working in harmony with celestial and zodiacal influences.

structure_content.summary: An overview of the grimoire's Solomonic attribution, its purpose in gaining wisdom from Chief Angels governing the four celestial Altitudes, and its place as Part IV within the broader Lemegeton tradition.

structure_content.chapter_title: Construction of the Almadel & Auxiliary Tools
structure_content.summary: Detailed instructions for crafting the central wax tablet (Almadel), including its precise dimensions (4 inches square, 6 inches thick/wide), color coding according to the Altitude, and specific inscriptions of God-names, pentacles, hexagram, and triangle. This section also covers the creation of the four supporting wax candles and the engraved golden seal.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Four Altitudes and Their Properties
structure_content.summary: A description of each of the four Altitudes (Choras) – corresponding to East, South, West, and North – detailing their specific virtues and powers (e.g., fruitfulness, wealth, increase, decrease), associated color schemes (lily-white, red rose, green/silver, black/dark green), and the lists of their respective ruling Angelic Princes.

A step-by-step guide for performing the invocation ritual, covering the physical setup of the Almadel, golden seal, and candles; preparation of the incense; lighting of the candles; and the recitation of the conjuration. It details the various forms of angelic appearance (initially as mist, then specific human/childlike figures) and the proper dialogue for communication.

Explanation of the crucial role of astrological timing, stipulating that angelic invocations must be strictly aligned with the Sun's current ingress into specific zodiacal signs (Cardinal, Fixed, and Mutable) that correspond to the ruling periods of the Altitude's Princes, always performed on a Sunday (Day of Sol).

The full verbatim text of the conjuration to call the Angels, with explicit instructions for the practitioner to personalize it by inserting the specific Angel's name and the appropriate God-names relevant to the Altitude being invoked.

structure_content.chapter_title: Afterword and Contextual Analysis by Benjamin Rowe
structure_content.summary: Benjamin Rowe's commentary provides critical historical and magical context, situating the Ars Almadel within the broader Lemegeton tradition. It clarifies the underlying cosmological framework of the Altitudes as seasonal and zodiacal rather than elemental, critiques alternative interpretations, and offers practical insights into the system's unique benevolent approach to angelic magic.

key_concepts.definition: The primary ritual device, a square wax tablet (4 inches square, 6 inches thick/wide), inscribed with divine names, pentacles, and geometric figures. It is color-coded to the invoking Altitude and serves as a manifestation base for the angels.

Four celestial divisions (East, South, West, North), each governing a season and three specific zodiacal signs. They are ruled by Chief Angels and Princes, each possessing distinct powers influencing natural and material phenomena, from fruitfulness to wealth.

Benevolent celestial beings associated with the Altitudes. Their appearance varies per Altitude, typically appearing in human-like or childlike forms with symbolic attributes (e.g., rose crowns, green/silver attire, holding a naked bird).

A foundational magical implement, preferably made of gold, engraved with the names HELION, HELLUION, ADONAIJ. It is used to empower the operation, mark the candles, and is placed upon the Almadel during the ritual.

Specific Hebrew and Gnostic names of God (e.g., ADONAIJ, HELOMI, PINE, TETRAGRAMMATON, SHADAI, JAH) inscribed upon the Almadel and recited in invocations. These names serve as vibrational keys to access and command celestial powers.
A powerful constraining name inscribed on the Almadel and incorporated into the invocation. Its purpose is to compel the Angel's visible and clear appearance during the ritual.

A core operative principle dictating that angelic invocations must be strictly aligned with the Sun's current position within specific zodiacal signs (Cardinal, Fixed, Mutable) that correspond to the ruling periods of the Altitude's Princes. All operations are to be performed on a Sunday (Day of Sol).
Small supports made from the same wax as the candles, designed to elevate the Almadel. This elevation creates space for an incense vessel to be placed directly beneath the tablet.

A fragrant resin, specifically mastick powder, used in the ritual. It is burned on hot coals in a vessel placed beneath the Almadel, allowing its fume to rise through the tablet's holes as an offering and a medium to attract the Angels.

practical_system.description: The 'Ars Almadel' is an operative system of Solomonic angelic magic focused on invoking Chief Angels and their Princes from four celestial 'Altitudes' or 'Choras'. The system is distinguished by its use of a specific wax tablet (the Almadel), precisely inscribed with divine names and symbols, and four accompanying candles. Operations are timed according to the day of Sol and, crucially, the Sun's position within the zodiac, aligning the invocation with the specific ruling Angels of that period. The Angels are benevolent and appear readily if properly invoked, without the need for coercive measures typically found in Goetic practices. The aim is to gain wisdom, influence aspects of generation, increase/decrease, wealth/poverty, and other specific outcomes related to the Angels' domains.
tools: Almadel (wax tablet, 4 inches square, 6 inches wide/thick)
Pure wax (lily-white for 1st Altitude, red for 2nd, green/silver for 3rd, black/dark green for 4th)
Four wax feet (to support Almadel from candles)
Golden Seal (or silver), engraved with HELION, HELLUION, ADONAIJ
Vessel of earth (basin-shaped, same color as Almadel)
Crystal stone (optional, small, placed on golden seal)
rituals: Construct the Almadel from pure wax (color-coded to the desired Altitude), 4 inches square, 6 inches thick/wide, with corner holes. Inscribe specific God-names and symbols (Pentacle of Solomon, Sexangle, Triangle, ANABONA) in designated positions.
Create four candles of the same wax and color as the Almadel, with wax feet to support the Almadel.
Engrave the Golden Seal with HELION, HELLUION, ADONAIJ. Write the specific invocation on virgin parchment.
Determine the current Sun's zodiacal sign and invoke only the Angels governing during that period, always on a Sunday (Day of Sol).
Place the Almadel on its wax feet between the four unlit candles (set on candlesticks). Lay the Golden Seal upon the Almadel.
Prepare a vessel of earth (basin-shaped, same color as Almadel) containing hot ashes/coals and three grains of mastick powder.
Light the four candles. Read the invocation from the virgin parchment, substituting 'N' with the Angel's name and the appropriate God-names for the specific Altitude.
Once the Angel appears (as a mist/fog first, then in specific forms), place the incense vessel under the Almadel so the fume rises through its holes.

The Angel will speak, asking the operator's desire. The operator must respond humbly, stating their requests for wisdom or specific outcomes, affirming that the Angel's office enables fulfillment if God wills it. If the Angel doesn't appear immediately, use the Golden Seal to make 3 or 4 marks on the candles.
Offer kind entertainment to the Angel, discuss just and lawful requests. Upon departure, the Angel will leave a pleasant scent.

relevant_quotes.text: By this art Solomon attained great wisdom from the Chief Angels that govern the four Altitudes of the World: for you must observe that there are four Altitudes which represent the four Corners of the West, East, North and South: the which is divided into 12 parts; that is, every part 3.

Make this Almadel of pure white wax; but the others must be coloured suitable to the Altitude. It is to be 4 inches square, and 6 inches over every way, and in every corner a hole, and write betwixt every hole with a new pen those words and names of God following.
And note you must not pray for any angel but those that belong to the Altitude you have a desire to call forth.

And when he appeareth he appeareth in the form of an Angel carrying in his hand a banner or flag having the picture of a white cross¹ upon it, his body being wrapped round with a fair cloud, and his face very fair and bright, and a crown of rose flowers upon his head.

Note that the other three Altitudes, with their Signs and Princes can exert power over goods and riches, and can make any man rich or poor. And as the first Chora gives increase and maketh fruitful, so these give decrease and barrenness.

Note there is twelve Princes, beside those in the four Altitudes: and they distribute their offices amongst themselves, every one ruling thirty days every year. Now it will be in vain to call any of the Angels unless it be those that govern then, for every Chora or altitude hath its limited time, according to the twelve signs of the Zodiack; and in that Sign the Sun is in, that or those Angels that belong to that Sign hath the government [and should be invoked].

It is interesting to note that as the powers to be invoked has become progres- sively more exalted, the method of invocation becomes progressively simpler. One prepares to invoke a Goetic spirit as if for a minor magickal war; a single work of the Almadel can be accomplished before breakfast. This accords with the medieval idea that spirits who are servants of God want to assist mankind, and will readily come if properly called; the threats and force used on the Goetic spirits are not required for the higher spirits, and would in fact be an insult to them.

The four Altitudes of the Almadel are not exactly cognate with the four direc- tions, or with the Elements. Rather they seem to be representatives of the equinox and solstice points, viewed as the anchor points of the zodiac and the seasons.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Ars Almadel' is a critical component of the 'Lemegeton', offering a distinct approach to angelic invocation compared to the more commonly known 'Goetia'. It represents a 'white magic' tradition within grimoires, emphasizing hierarchical celestial powers, cooperation with divine servants, and a less confrontational operative style. Its detailed instructions for constructing the Almadel and aligning operations with zodiacal periods provide a sophisticated system of celestial magic, influencing later Hermetic and Golden Dawn currents. The afterword's clarification of the Altitudes' seasonal/zodiacal nature significantly enhances the understanding of its underlying cosmological framework, making it highly relevant for practitioners seeking a gentler, more harmonically aligned form of angelic conjuration.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Practicing magicians, occultists, and scholars of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Solomonic magic, grimoire traditions, angelic evocation, and astrological timing in ritual work. It is suitable for those who have a foundational understanding of ceremonial magic and are looking for a system focused on benevolent celestial entities and the acquisition of wisdom or specific blessings.
